question: Comment on the diagnosis:
exp: Ans. (b) Buphthalmos.* Infantile glaucoma, which often produces the clinical sign of Buphthalmos, can be caused when an abnormally narrow angle between the cornea and iris blocks the outflow of aqueous humor; this causes increased intraocular pressure and eventual enlargement of the globe (eyeball).* The predominant signs are prominent eyeball, Haab's striae in Descemet's membrane of cornea, enlarged cornea, myopia.

question: What is not true about congenital glaucoma of eye?
exp: Ans. is 'd' i.e., Anterior chamber is shallow o On examination following findings are therei) First sign is corneal edema with watering of eye with marked photophobia.ii) Haab striae (Discrete corneal opacities appear as lines with double contour due to rupture in Descemet's membrane).iii) Cornea is hazy with frosted glass appearance.iv) Corneal enlargementv) Thin & blue scleravi) Deep anterior chambervii) Lens is antero- posteriorly flat and may be subluxated backward, viii) Iridodonesis (tremulous iris) and atrophic patch on iris.ix) Large eye (Buphthalmos or hydrophthalmos)x) Variable cupping and atrophy of discxi) Raised IOP (neither acute nor marked)
